content.html:
I consider authoring CSS to be where I can stream-of-consciousness code the best. All through the time before PHP was a thing, I was using CSS and HTML. I have continued through today. These two are truly the only technical languages that I have had in regular use the entire time I have been at the show.

I remember when HTML gained dynamic properties. It was Dynamic HTML, DHTML. The actuality of it was inlining JavaScript in HTML attributes, iirc. When I picked up JS for the first time, the marketers were calling it DHTML to appeal to the established market.

lol, omg I'm getting old.

Writing CSS is expressive and just flows. It's pretty fun to run the keyboard while another describes what should change or how things should move around, and so on, and then one types the exact CSS that does what was described in plain non-technical language a moment before so that the person can "design" and receive the "designed" in real-time and interactively without the technical acumen on their own. It's fun, totally worth the practice. It's a bit like playing guitar for people's entertainment, but here they have an instrument of a sort to play too if they have their imaginations along.

It's much different, for me, when efficiency is on the table too, as it is with c/c++, php, even with JS programming. I am hyper-aware of all the crap that comes out of my keyboard and try to keep the flow to a minimum there. I can do that well enough. pretty good I wouldn't say it's stressful, it's not, but it is ... all-encompassing. I am wholly absorbed in authorship and have only but little room to fit in the 'just for fun.'

Maybe I should take a little holiday from serious-coding and do something just for the joy of it. On my time of course, I love my F/T backend coding team/job/gains.

Nowadays there is Sass and maybe some other pre-processors. A whole other adventure awaits with tailwindcss and similar. Man, It's so weird that JS ate everything. Oh and TypeScript is chewing on JS, yes! I should look at TS too. But, then again, that is a microsoft thing and each of those is are usually a pretty serious endeavour, endeavours not for the faint of heart. Hmm. I'll check it out sometime.

Ah, all this to say, I like and miss CSS, and decided to pick-up Sass this go. I'm not using a framework because a) don't need too; b) won't take long without one; and c) learning not earning. I wrote up a realistical HTML homepage for an imaginary business and then swapped out/in each of three or four frameworks and their build pipelines to see how it was. I tried tailwindcss, foundation-sites, bootstrap 5 (pro bs 3 guy here), and checked the repos on some others: bulma, materialize, tachyons, milligram.

For the most part, I found the frameworks did more than I wanted them too. Certainly Certianly much more than I needed them too. But in the end it would take me quite a long time to see the forest (to remove) for the tree (for the clubhouse).

Fresh start, good times, ciao~!

These two are truly the only technical languages that I have had in regular use the entire time I have been at the show.I remember when HTML gained dynamic properties. It was Dynamic HTML, DHTML. content.html:
I grew up with gaming and I like to make things. I like to work, a lot.

I have been writing computer programs since the unix timestamp had half the runtime it has now. ½tunix!
content.value:
I grew up with gaming and I like to make things. I like to work, a lot.
            I have been writing computer programs since the unix timestamp had half the runtime it has now. ½tunix!

content.html: The 'updated' time stamp on each post I publish here is the last modified date on the file that stores the content. The time stamp may update because I change the post content, or post metadata like the tags. The timestamp also follows those changes I make to the file metadata also.
content.value: The 'updated' time stamp on each post I publish here is the last modified date on the file that stores the content. The time stamp may update because I change the post content, or post metadata like the tags. The timestamp also follows those changes I make to the file metadata also.

content.html:
100% 03:38 AM

NASA
Astronomy Pic of the Day

  • 6am???
  • 9am???
  • noon???
  • 3pm???
  • 6pm???
  • 9pm???
content.value:
100%
				
			
			
				03:38 AM			
		
		
			
		
		NASAAstronomy Pic of the Day
	
		
		6am???
		9am???
		noon???
		3pm???
		6pm???
		9pm???

My browser homepage is https://search.brave.com/ but when I type in the address bar the web search results are from https://duckduckgo.com/.

  The featured screen snippet is an inline preview in the response from ddg when I searched up harmonic. 
  

That image is fascinating. It reminds me of a moire pattern, but it isn't. I clicked through to the page for a closer look 
When I arrived at the Wikipedia page for Harmonic, I found that the dark area in this image ^^^ was white. Ruined.

  So back to ddg, and hence this screen snippet!

The weather is mainly cloudy at 12.1°C (53.8°F) with winds in the West steady at 10.6 m/s (38 km/h; 23 mph).

The relative humidity is 63% at an air pressure of 0.993 atm (1006 mbar).

It's 3:39am ADT. The sun will rise 3 hours from now, or so.

content.html:
"What's that d'ya reckon?" "What d'ya reckon's goin' on there?"

I (tried) to look up 'reckoning' and 'reckon' on the wikipedia. There's a redirect to "Counting."

My usage? d'ya reckon: an informal request for 2 cents.

cjw6k: "Who do you reckon won the vote?"
amph: "Depends who you ask."
cjw6k: "No it doesn't it depends who you asked, silly bean."

Wha'd'ya reckon?
content.value: "What's that d'ya reckon?" "What d'ya reckon's goin' on there?"I (tried) to look up 'reckoning' and 'reckon' on the wikipedia. There's a redirect to "Counting."My usage? d'ya reckon: an informal request for 2 cents.cjw6k: "Who do you reckon won the vote?"amph: "Depends who you ask."cjw6k: "No it doesn't it depends who you asked, silly bean."Wha'd'ya reckon?
